subject: Law
title: State Recognition and Statehood
description: One-minute skill: State Recognition and Statehood.

hook.text: Taiwan has its own government, military, and economy. But most countries don't recognize it as a state.

buildup.text: Statehood requires a permanent population, defined territory, government, and capacity for foreign relations.

discovery.text: These criteria come from the 1933 Montevideo Convention. Meeting them doesn't guarantee recognition, though.

twist.text: Recognition is political. Kosovo declared independence in 2008; some nations recognize it, others don't.

climax.text: Without recognition, a territory struggles to join international bodies, sign treaties, or access global finance.

punchline.text: Being a state and being recognized as one aren't the same thing.

quiz.question: What convention outlines the criteria for statehood?
